title: "Don't play ranked if you can't play X role"
body:
Okay, this saying is starting to piss me off.

First, I'm an AP mage main. I "main" mid lane and support. I play an okay top, a meh adc, and a below average jungler. 

I'm not going to spend time practicing my 5th role, because I only get it (If i'm lucky) every 10-15 games. 

"Lol then how are you even Plat?"  Because I'm good at my other roles. I'm a Plat level mid-support, I'm probably a silver level jungler. When I get that position more often than not I'm against a jungler main. 

It's seriously stupid to expect every player to be godlike at every role. There's a reason people call out their preferences. Yes, you won't always get your role and you should be knowledgeable of the basics for every role. 

Even pro players usually only play their one role, but they always get it because they have name recognition.

I have to disagree with you on your title, you should have basic enough knowledge to play each role.
Should you be able to play every role perfectly? No.
The reason I say this is because you get people who say: "I can only play mid"
Ok, but the next team your with might not care. At some point, you WILL BE EXPECTED TO PLAY YOUR WORST OR LEAST FAVOURITE ROLE. 

Asides from that, it's rude to all the players who do make sacrifices, and play for the team. What your time is too important to not bother learning?

I was going to say something like this, but you said it before me.

Every player is going to be better at one or two roles than another, and going to be worse at one or two roles than another. Having basic knowledge of all of those roles is practically mandatory for playing Ranked in case you get picked with your worst role.

You don't have to be good at that role, you just have to be not bad at the role.

I don't do ranked, so I could be wrong, but after silver isn't a "basic knowledge" of a role not good enough? Thought that silver/low gold represented basic knowledge and not much further, and in say Gold I if a player gets stuck in a role in which he/she has only basic knowledge of and is pitted against someone who mains that role, he/she is going to get steamrolled.

At higher levels of skill/rank what is considered basic knowledge increases. Take ADC for an example at low levels it is just enough to safely farm. Then at some point you are expected to know how to follow up/work with the support. Then comes understanding of trading while CSing; and then on.

Literally the only reason I don't main AD Carry is because my internet is being upgraded so it will be great but right now I could easily DC for a couple of seconds in a teamfight and lose the game.

Uhh... It's a video game that has 5 roles. None of them are overly complicated if you make intelligent decisions

ADC: Farm as much as possible, poke when its safe. Try not to over engage with support.
Support: Try to zone enemy with position, get ADC as much farm as possible without going too hard. Don't do risky engages. Ward a lot.
Mid: Don't feed, farm a lot, and look for roams.
Top: Don't feed, farm as much as possible.
Jungler: Know where enemy jungler is, support your lanes as much as possible to build momentum. Don't fall behind in levels.

Of course there are all sorts of things that encompass "playing the game good" throughout the game but that's an extremely generalized early game for each role.

"I ONLY PLAY MID IM LEAVING IF I GET STUCK AS SUPP"

Like I would rather have someone stomp on the floor above me for an hour that read some ass hat crying about how they play one role because thats what LCS teams do.

Every pro in this game supposedly has a "main role" and a "champion pool" but you don't get to challenger by playing like a bronze 5 when you have to play another role.

I believe its a delusion that you should expect to play your "main role" and "favorite champion" in every game to win. The reality is champions aren't that hard to learn even if it means watching a good person play that champion a few times to get some strategy hints. I have been in 4000+ games and nothing is more irritating than someone blaming their poor performance on a role they don't want to play. 

TL DR: I disagree with your post.

I disagree with this, heavily, namely the last part. I get my role 7/10 games I play, so if I was any good, I could carry myself, say for me, to gold, if I made few mistakes in 5 or 6/7 of the seven games I got, and probably win 1-2 of the other games, and that isn't going to  make you a better mid laner, or adc, or jungler.

I suck at adc, because I normally play people like olaf, aatrox, or hecarim, where their role, is to kill the enemy carries as fast as possible regardless of opposition, so when I go into a game as adc, I am not used to kiting, I am used to charging, I am not used to not being able to take one skill shot of damage, you simply aren't used to what the said role entails, yes you will pick up on things as time goes on, but are still not going to be any good is most of your games if you are facing someone that plays that role normally.

Me, my awareness of where to be at a given time is shit. If dragon is up, I try to stay at bot side, and that is about as far as my ability as a jungler goes, and the one mid laner I can play reliably is Karthus, because I am only an okay viktor for elo -- at best, so I end up picking karth basically every time I have to go mid, because he is the one mid I understand to a level where he is playable at my elo.

I think people should at least have a small pool of champions for each role, but to expect someone to be proficient at every role? That is insane, and quite simply ridiculous, because if someone is in their habits of another role, whether or not it is intentional, it is going to carry over most likely.

If you want to win, let people play their main.

> [{quoted}](name=UnknownToPublic,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iZrbej9h,comment-id=003e,timestamp=2015-08-30T20:18:13.765+0000)
>
> no one really gives a fuck what your main is,you must be prepared to play every role without being completely failure.

Is knowing more than one role a good idea? Yes.

Is knowing only one role a good idea? No.

Is knowing all five roles a requirement for ranked? No, that's just too generalizing. You should have a role you're good at, practice it, and just have a backup or two just in case. 

In my opinion, I think it's fair that a player should understand the basics of jungling (pathing, how smite buffs work, and ganking/farming junglers), how different carries carry, and at least support basics (because everyone gets that one last pick). Know one of the solo lane roles, support basics, and either adc or jungle is one good way to do it, but not the rule.

This advice is for yolo queue and mostly for your own benefit. No one is saying you can't have a preference or you have to be godlike in every role. But everyone and their grandmother is a "mid or top" main - there will be times you draw the short stick and get whatever is left, so its really for your own benefit to get _**decent **_ at all of them.

Yeah, your title is very misleading. 

There is a big difference between "I dont know how to play X role" and "I'm not too great at X role"

Some people refuse to play  a role and will troll champ select because they "dont know how to play X role". The title seems to encourage players to not learn other roles, and by that merit, discourages teamwork outside of the current game. It's a team game, learn the team dynamic.

On the other hand, I agree with you that it is complete bullshit for people to call out "lol how are you plat/diamond if you aren't godlike in X role".
I've been Diamond the last two seasons and my mid-lane is about as good as a Silver elo player, but my top-lane and jungling is Diamond level. I can hardly play mid-lane in normal queues without someone remarking about my rank and how my shitty mid-lane skills don't align with my rank. "No shit Sherlock that's why I'm not going out of my way to play mid-lane in ranked queues"

I agree with OP.  People who say that are just being stupid.  

There are two ways to be on average a plat level player.  Be plat skilled at all roles equally and therefore have the same chance to win regardless of role, or be high plat skilled at one or two roles, enough to make up for the difference of the losses when you get stuck in other roles (which will happen infrequently enough to maintain rank).  Whether they realize it or not, most players are much better at some roles than others.  Brow beating someone for admitting it in champ select is foolish and anyone doing the brow beating and forcing someone into their worst position deserves their loss, particularly since it probably resulted in the unlucky circumstance of too many people maining the same roles getting matched together.

That's just a shortcoming of the system, not the player.

What you have to realize is the other team is dealing with the same issue, and probably has one or more people playing out of position too.

My problem with the 'Don't play ranked if you can't play X' argument is the fact that the person saying it usually expects you to play it as well as an actual main.  You might know the basics of the role, but you're still going to get stomped since you have maybe 50 games of experience in that role and the other guy, who mains that role, has 500.  They know all the little things you don't and they most likely know how to exploit the mistakes inexperienced people often make.
